name: OHenry - From the Cabby’s Seat
body:
The cabby has his point of view. It is more single-minded, perhaps, than that
of a follower of any other calling. From the high, swaying seat of his hansom
he looks upon his fellow-men as nomadic particles, of no account except when
possessed of migratory desires. He is Jehu, and you are goods in transit. Be
you President or vagabond, to cabby you are only a Fare, he takes you up,
cracks his whip, joggles your vertebrae and sets you down.


When time for payment arrives, if you exhibit a familiarity with legal rates
you come to know what contempt is; if you find that you have left your
pocketbook behind you are made to realise the mildness of Danteâs
imagination.


It is not an extravagant theory that the cabbyâs singleness of purpose
and concentrated view of life are the results of the hansomâs peculiar
construction. The cock-of-the-roost sits aloft like Jupiter on an unsharable
seat, holding your fate between two thongs of inconstant leather. Helpless,
ridiculous, confined, bobbing like a toy mandarin, you sit like a rat in a
trapâyou, before whom butlers cringe on solid landâand must squeak
upward through a slit in your peripatetic sarcophagus to make your feeble
wishes known.


Then, in a cab, you are not even an occupant; you are contents. You are a cargo
at sea, and the âcherub that sits up aloftâ has Davy Jonesâs
street and number by heart.


One night there were sounds of revelry in the big brick tenement-house next
door but one to McGaryâs Family CafÃ©. The sounds seemed to emanate from
the apartments of the Walsh family. The sidewalk was obstructed by an
assortment of interested neighbours, who opened a lane from time to time for a
hurrying messenger bearing from McGaryâs goods pertinent to festivity and
diversion. The sidewalk contingent was engaged in comment and discussion from
which it made no effort to eliminate the news that Norah Walsh was being
married.


In the fulness of time there was an eruption of the merry-makers to the
sidewalk. The uninvited guests enveloped and permeated them, and upon the night
air rose joyous cries, congratulations, laughter and unclassified noises born
of McGaryâs oblations to the hymeneal scene.


Close to the curb stood Jerry OâDonovanâs cab. Night-hawk was Jerry
called; but no more lustrous or cleaner hansom than his ever closed its doors
upon point lace and November violets. And Jerryâs horse! I am within
bounds when I tell you that he was stuffed with oats until one of those old
ladies who leave their dishes unwashed at home and go about having expressmen
arrested, would have smiledâyes, smiledâto have seen him.


Among the shifting, sonorous, pulsing crowd glimpses could be had of
Jerryâs high hat, battered by the winds and rains of many years; of his
nose like a carrot, battered by the frolicsome, athletic progeny of
millionaires and by contumacious fares; of his brass-buttoned green coat,
admired in the vicinity of McGaryâs. It was plain that Jerry had usurped
the functions of his cab, and was carrying a âload.â Indeed, the
figure may be extended and he be likened to a bread-waggon if we admit the
testimony of a youthful spectator, who was heard to remark âJerry has got
a bun.â


From somewhere among the throng in the street or else out of the thin stream of
pedestrians a young woman tripped and stood by the cab. The professional
hawkâs eye of Jerry caught the movement. He made a lurch for the cab,
overturning three or four onlookers and himselfâno! he caught the cap of
a water-plug and kept his feet. Like a sailor shinning up the ratlins during a
squall Jerry mounted to his professional seat. Once he was there McGaryâs
liquids were baffled. He seesawed on the mizzenmast of his craft as safe as a
Steeple Jack rigged to the flagpole of a skyscraper.


âStep in, lady,â said Jerry, gathering his lines. The young woman
stepped into the cab; the doors shut with a bang; Jerryâs whip cracked in
the air; the crowd in the gutter scattered, and the fine hansom dashed away
âcrosstown.


When the oat-spry horse had hedged a little his first spurt of speed Jerry
broke the lid of his cab and called down through the aperture in the voice of a
cracked megaphone, trying to please:


âWhere, now, will ye be drivinâ to?â


âAnywhere you please,â came up the answer, musical and contented.


ââTis drivinâ for pleasure she is,â thought Jerry. And
then he suggested as a matter of course:


âTake a thrip around in the park, lady. âTwill be ilegant cool and
fine.â


âJust as you like,â answered the fare, pleasantly.


The cab headed for Fifth avenue and sped up that perfect street. Jerry bounced
and swayed in his seat. The potent fluids of McGary were disquieted and they
sent new fumes to his head. He sang an ancient song of Killisnook and
brandished his whip like a baton.


Inside the cab the fare sat up straight on the cushions, looking to right and
left at the lights and houses. Even in the shadowed hansom her eyes shone like
stars at twilight.


When they reached Fifty-ninth street Jerryâs head was bobbing and his
reins were slack. But his horse turned in through the park gate and began the
old familiar nocturnal round. And then the fare leaned back, entranced, and
breathed deep the clean, wholesome odours of grass and leaf and bloom. And the
wise beast in the shafts, knowing his ground, struck into his by-the-hour gait
and kept to the right of the road.


Habit also struggled successfully against Jerryâs increasing torpor. He
raised the hatch of his storm-tossed vessel and made the inquiry that cabbies
do make in the park.


âLike shtop at the Cas-sino, lady? Gezzer râfreshmâs,
ân lishân the music. Evâbody shtops.â


âI think that would be nice,â said the fare.


They reined up with a plunge at the Casino entrance. The cab doors flew open.
The fare stepped directly upon the floor. At once she was caught in a web of
ravishing music and dazzled by a panorama of lights and colours. Some one
slipped a little square card into her hand on which was printed a
numberâ34. She looked around and saw her cab twenty yards away already
lining up in its place among the waiting mass of carriages, cabs and motor
cars. And then a man who seemed to be all shirt-front danced backward before
her; and next she was seated at a little table by a railing over which climbed
a jessamine vine.


There seemed to be a wordless invitation to purchase; she consulted a
collection of small coins in a thin purse, and received from them license to
order a glass of beer. There she sat, inhaling and absorbing it allâthe
new-coloured, new-shaped life in a fairy palace in an enchanted wood.


At fifty tables sat princes and queens clad in all the silks and gems of the
world. And now and then one of them would look curiously at Jerryâs fare.
They saw a plain figure dressed in a pink silk of the kind that is tempered by
the word âfoulard,â and a plain face that wore a look of love of
life that the queens envied.


Twice the long hands of the clocks went round, Royalties thinned from their
al fresco thrones, and buzzed or clattered away in their vehicles of
state. The music retired into cases of wood and bags of leather and baize.
Waiters removed cloths pointedly near the plain figure sitting almost alone.


Jerryâs fare rose, and held out her numbered card simply:


âIs there anything coming on the ticket?â she asked.


A waiter told her it was her cab check, and that she should give it to the man
at the entrance. This man took it, and called the number. Only three hansoms
stood in line. The driver of one of them went and routed out Jerry asleep in
his cab. He swore deeply, climbed to the captainâs bridge and steered his
craft to the pier. His fare entered, and the cab whirled into the cool
fastnesses of the park along the shortest homeward cuts.


At the gate a glimmer of reason in the form of sudden suspicion seized upon
Jerryâs beclouded mind. One or two things occurred to him. He stopped his
horse, raised the trap and dropped his phonographic voice, like a lead plummet,
through the aperture:


âI want to see four dollars before goinâ any further on thâ
thrip. Have ye got thâ dough?â


âFour dollars!â laughed the fare, softly, âdear me, no.
Iâve only got a few pennies and a dime or two.â


Jerry shut down the trap and slashed his oat-fed horse. The clatter of hoofs
strangled but could not drown the sound of his profanity. He shouted choking
and gurgling curses at the starry heavens; he cut viciously with his whip at
passing vehicles; he scattered fierce and ever-changing oaths and imprecations
along the streets, so that a late truck driver, crawling homeward, heard and
was abashed. But he knew his recourse, and made for it at a gallop.


At the house with the green lights beside the steps he pulled up. He flung wide
the cab doors and tumbled heavily to the ground.


âCome on, you,â he said, roughly.


His fare came forth with the Casino dreamy smile still on her plain face. Jerry
took her by the arm and led her into the police station. A gray-moustached
sergeant looked keenly across the desk. He and the cabby were no strangers.


âSargeant,â began Jerry in his old raucous, martyred, thunderous
tones of complaint. âIâve got a fare here thatââ


Jerry paused. He drew a knotted, red hand across his brow. The fog set up by
McGary was beginning to clear away.


âA fare, sargeant,â he continued, with a grin, âthat I want
to inthroduce to ye. Itâs me wife that I married at ould man
Walshâs this avening. And a divil of a time we had, âtis thrue.
Shake hands wid thâ sargeant, Norah, and weâll be off to
home.â


Before stepping into the cab Norah sighed profoundly.


âIâve had such a nice time, Jerry,â said she.
